Booking.description: Represents a booking made by a user for a property.

userId.description: The UID of the user who made the booking.

propertyId.description: The ID of the property being booked.

checkInDate.description: The check-in date for the booking.

checkOutDate.description: The check-out date for the booking.

totalPrice.description: The total price for the booking.

guests.description: The number of guests for the booking.

Message.description: Represents a single message in a chat conversation.

propertyId.description: The ID of the favorited property.

createdAt.description: The timestamp when the property was favorited.

Document.title: Document
Document.description: Represents a document uploaded by a user.

userId.description: The UID of the user who uploaded the document.

fileName.description: The name of the uploaded file.

fileUrl.description: The URL to access the uploaded file.

SavedSearch.title: SavedSearch
SavedSearch.description: Represents a user's saved search filters.

id.description: Unique identifier for the saved search.

name.description: The name given to the search by the user.

createdAt.description: The timestamp when the search was saved.

Visit.title: Visit
Visit.description: Represents a request to visit a property.

Announcement.title: Announcement
Announcement.description: Represents a system-wide announcement or newsletter.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore structure is designed to securely manage admin and user profiles using a path-based ownership model. This approach provides authorization independence and facilitates secure list operations.

**Authorization Independence:** Admin profiles are stored under the `/admin_profiles/{adminId}` path. Authorization is based solely on the `adminId` matching the `request.auth.uid`. There's no reliance on data from other documents to determine access.

**Structural Segregation:** Admin profiles are stored in a dedicated collection (`/admin_profiles`), ensuring a homogeneous security posture. All documents in this collection share the same security requirements (only the admin can access their profile).

**Access Modeling:** Path-based ownership is used for user data (`/users/{userId}`), admin data (`/admin_profiles/{adminId}`), and user-specific subcollections like favorites (`/users/{userId}/favorites`), documents (`/users/{userId}/documents`), and saved searches (`/users/{userId}/savedSearches`).

**QAPs:**
*   Secure `list` operations for user profiles are enabled for admins, while non-admins can only read their own profile.
*   The structure avoids using rules as filters, ensuring that list operations are secure and efficient.
